title: Bertie Plays the Blues
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Paysage Moralisé For Bertie Pollock, Saturday brought few surprises. The  day began, as Saturdays always did, with a walk to Valvona  & Crolla with his mother and Ulysses, his younger brother,  whose pushchair Bertie was allowed to propel along  London Street as far as the Broughton Street roundabout. Then his mother took over for the ascent towards Albany  Street.

title: Bertie Plays the Blues
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: "One's journey  is easy at the beginning but becomes more arduous as time  goes by. Thus Drummond Place and London Street are not  particularly challenging, but then one encounters Broughton  Street and it becomes more taxing. It is exactly the same  with life: it's simple at the beginning, Bertie, but it gets  steadily more complex."

title: Espresso Tales
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: "That bus goes along Princes Street and ends up on Leith Walk. If he took that, he would have to walk along London Street and then up to the top of Leith Walk. It's a slightly longer route, but there's another factor involved there."

title: The World According to Bertie
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: They continued down London Street, with Bertie throwing the occasional glance over his shoulder at the car. Now they went up the hill, up Broughton Street and into Union Street, in the direction of Leith Walk.

title: 44 Scotland Street
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: "Bertie," she said, as they walked back along London Street, "Mummy is very, very cross with you for writing that Miss Macfadzean is a cow. You should not have said it.

title: The World According to Bertie
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Their car might be old, but their baby buggy, at least, was brand-new. In fact, as they rounded the corner into London Street, Bertie saw their car, parked on the other side of the road.

title: Espresso Tales
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: "Going along London Street would remind him of the walk to the nursery school," she said quietly. "That's the route which I took him to that . . . that place."

title: 44 Scotland Street
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: They were now at the end of London Street. The nursery was not far away.
